content.description: Low, sustained crux to gain classic E-Rock steep face climbing
content.location: In between Top Gun and Megabyte, the start traverses an obvious but small ledge to the right.

content.description: Climb the southeast arete of The Frog. Delicate movement.
content.location: On the southeast arete at the mouth of the chimney.

content.description: Beautiful climbing on huge crystals up a wonderfully featured face. This is one of the best climbs in the area for its variety of movement.
content.protection: 3 bolts to an anchor. You can get small to medium pro in the horizontal crack a bit past the halfway point.
content.location: To the right of Megabyte. Start in a small alcove on the north side of The Frog.

content.description:
Very small holds and sustained climbing all the way to the top. Technical and balancey crux moves between the first and second bolts, moderate 5.11 runout to the third bolt but you won't hit the ground.  Optional to place gear in the Frog crack but the hard climbing is over by then,

 First ascent 1989 and was drilled on lead with hooks.
content.protection: 5 bolts, top 2 shared with Velvet Elvis, to an anchor.
content.location: Starts in a pit between Velvet Elvis and Tonka Toys From Hell.

content.description: A horizontal crack that traverses left along The Frog deposits you in an alcove for easier climbing to the summit.
content.location: Starts just to the left of the Easy Wall access slab on the back of The Frog.

content.description: An engaging and worthwhile adventure at the grade!  Stem up the chimney, stand on the detached boulder and clip the bolt.  Get into the jugs on the main Frog formation and pull yourself over the lip (chossy).  Climb easier terrain to the bolts.  One guidebook says set an belay in the "alcove" above the bolt, but that is pointless, rope drag can easily be mitigated by extending draws and is a non-issue.
content.protection: Bolt and you can get in stuff in the .5 range if you want.
content.location: On the left side of The Frog there is an obvious chimney.

content.description: Low angle slab at the back can be used to access the summit and set up a toprope with gear. A #7 tricam and an extra rope will get it done.
content.location: The obvious low angle slab on the back of The Frog.

content.description: A large boulder which looks like a frog if viewed from the Echo Canyon Trail or the Main Dome. This nice, semi-secluded area is host to a few truly quality climbs. The face climbing in this spot is very steep and very fun. The original guidebook gives most everything in the area full stars.
